name: Theatre Mysteries Multiple Choice Quiz | Literature | 10 Questions

questions.text: In my opinion, the best play of the genre is 'Sleuth'. Who wrote it?
questions.explanation:
Anthony Shaffer.

	Brilliant writing by Anthony Shaffer - who never quite found the formula again. 'Murderer' and 'Whodunit' were his - but they were pale imitations which enjoyed (deservedly) only modest success. (Don't judge this fine play by the mediocre movie version that followed).

questions.text: 'Equus' is a bit of a stretch here. The play doesn't deal with identifying who committed the crime; it focuses on a different issue.
questions.explanation:
Why the crime was committed.

	We know from the start who did the deed, but the question is: why did he do it? A psychological piece from the talented writer who gave us 'Black Comedy' and 'Amadeus', among other fine works.

questions.text: 'Mousetrap' was a huge hit with a long, long run. Who wrote it?
questions.explanation:
Agatha Christie.

	One of the earliest mystery plays to have a big success.

questions.text: This play is the longest running off-Broadway non-musical.
questions.explanation:
'Perfect Crime'.

	'Murderer' and 'Whodunit' are by Anthony Shaffer - (see comments to question 1). 'Getting Away' is co-authored by (of all people) Stephen Sondheim. Why 'Perfect Crime' has done so well is a mystery to me: it's not very good.

questions.text: The author of 'Deathtrap' also wrote this popular novel.
questions.explanation:
'Rosemary's Baby'.

	Ira Levin wrote both. 'Deathtrap' has been very successful, but it has a weak second act and a weaker ending. Go figure.

questions.text: 'The Letter' was turned into a good Bette Davis movie. Who was the author of the play?
questions.explanation:
Somerset Maugham.

	It was Maugham ('Of Human Bondage'). Again, we know who committed the crime - the question is: why did she do it?

questions.text: 'Witness for the Prosecution' was a big hit. To whom does the title refer?
questions.explanation:
The suspect's wife.

	Marlene Dietrich in the fine movie version with Charles Laughton.

questions.text: 'Murder in the Cathedral' may not fit comfortably with the other entries here, but it does concern murder. Who wrote it?
questions.explanation:
T.S. Eliot

	Yes, he did plays, too.

questions.text: Shakespeare's 'Macbeth' was described as 'The Macbeth Murder Mystery' in a famous essay by this writer.
questions.explanation:
James Thurber.

	Cute idea, I guess.

questions.text: 'Ten Little Indians' was a classic whodunit. By which of these other titles is it also known?
questions.explanation:
And Then There Were None.

	There are too many movie versions of this to count. Some work well, some are less fortunate.
